title: scarlett moffatt tribe next door
story: No sooner have you pointed out Caravanning With Shane Richie, on Channel , is “the full ­Partridge,” then along comes something even more random which blows the comparison out of the water.Last week, that something was Channel ’s The British Tribe Next Door, featuring Scarlett Moffatt and her family, from ­Gogglebox, and the semi- nomadic Himba people of Namibia’s northern uplands.An idea, which in terms of personnel and ­location is the trippiest thing since the  Watch masterpiece Singing In The Rainforest, with The Happy ­Mondays.This part of Africa is ­actually a much more well-trodden path for TV people, though, and off the top of my head I can remember Eddie Izzard, Ian Wright and Steve Jones all doing something pretty similar hereabouts.We’re also familiar with the patronising, self-loathing tone of these cultural exchange documentaries and must accept every Third World tribe is infinitely ­superior, wiser and more dignied than us, for they cherish the Earth, have remembered all the precious things we’ve forgotten and blah blah blah.What set this apart from all previous brain farts was Channel  also decided to rebuild the Moffatts’ house, slap bang in the middle of the Himba’s camp, ­complete with , household objects, electricity, water supply, wi, doorbell and full on-demand television.Questions should immediately spring to mind here, starting with why  What the f***  And would it not have been easier to take Jenny and Lee’s static caravan, from Hull,they really had to send someone from Gogglebox You also have to wonder how long it’ll be before the Moffatts get the first ring on that doorbell from the local Jehovah’s Witnesses.The real trouble with an idea as nuts as The British Tribe Next Door, though, is that short of killing or marrying one of the Moffatts, there is almost no chance the four-part series will be anything like as deranged or interesting as the madness of the commissioning process.In the event, the Himba people were fairly thunderstruck by the appearance of the Moffatts’ semi-detached house, from Bishop Auckland, with its mirrors, ­washing machine and staircase.But not quite as thunderstruck as the blokes were by Mike the dad’s metal- detecting equipment, and the topless Himba women were with Scarlett’s ­knockers.So struck, in fact, they spent most of the first episode trying to persuade her to get them out, until eventually she began ­weeping about her “body confidence” issues and the penny dropped.It’s not really about the Himba people at all.It’s just another stupid documentary about us and our contrived First World problems.This isn’t the first time it’s been done this month either. Harry and Meghan went to Africa, with ITV, and made that trip all about their own anxieties and issues as well, without being half as engaging or sympathetic as Scarlett Moffatt.If anything, I think The British Tribe Next Door will also live longer in my memory than the royal version, not least because C seems to have got more than it bargained for with the Himba, who clearly aren’t big on marital fidelity.Some of the men are already looking to pick off Scarlett from the back of the Moffatt herd and episode one ended with this tantalising offer, from one of the women to her mum.“Betty, let us swap husbands tonight.” .So my interest in this show is now over.DAVID ATTENBOROUGH’S Seven Worlds, One Planet lived up to the usual visually stunning expectations for nearly an hour on Sunday night on BBC.A couple of cute baby animals won their struggle for le, two gender-fluid gastropods had it off at the bottom of the Antarctic Ocean and a bull elephant seal on South Georgia discovered: “cm of blubber is protection against the cold, but not from a four-ton opponent” – a bit like Tess Holliday did when Piers Morgan went for her on Twitter.The environmental message was also conveyed, in no uncertain terms, as the seas warmed, glaciers melted and an albatross chick almost got blown to buggery.Then,  minutes into the show, we were suddenly back on South Georgia, with Rolf the seasick cameraman, who was in front of the lens this time and so overcome by the fate of the penguins, and the future of the planet, he began sobbing like Rylan Clark-Neal just after Nicole Scherzinger had put him through to live shows.All the most pointless, virtue-signalling extinction rebels in the country were probably joining in with this gesture as well, even though it’s a moot point as to how close we are exactly to environmental Armageddon.What you can say with a little more certainty, though, is that the moment it starts trying to turn a David Attenborough documentary into an X Factor sob story it’s probably the beginning of the end for the BBC.THE Last Leg, Adam Hills: “Out of ­interest, what would we all dothis ­fabulous industry we’re in fell through for us and we had to go and find a job ”Have you ever considered comedy X Factor: Celebrity, Jenny Ryan: “It’s time for me to share what I’ve got with the world.”Jonathan Ross: “He’s the host of the very funny Mash Report. He’s a fabulous stand-up, Nish Kumar.”And X Factor: Celebrity, Simon Cowell to No Love Lost: “For all the doubters who thought this was going to be a car crash, you’ve proved a point.”It’s a car crash.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “The term Martians refers to the supposed inhabitants of which planet ”Lucie: “Pass.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What Champion­ship team was originally called The Wednesday Football Club ”Orchid: “Tottenham Spurs.”Ben Shephard: “Which th Century military conflict is also known as The Great War ”Ben Shephard: “In a classic novel by Johanna Spyri, what is the name of the orphan sent to live with her grandfather in the Swiss Alps ”Steph: “Anne Frank.”CHANNEL  disclaimer of the week: “Be prepared right from the very start for graphic scenes of consensual bondage, sadomasochism, dominant and submissive sexual activity, dangerous procedures which only trained professionals should try, nudity and offensive language, all of which are likely to disturb some viewers.”And what an episode of Toot The Tiny Tugboat that was.SATURDAY’S first live episode of X Factor: Celebrity was an assault on two of your senses.The show now looks like it’s set in the display ring of a Herefordshire livestock market, but sounds more like the local abattoir during “Sunday roast” rush hour.Seriously, you dub Jenny Ryan or Ricki Lake singing Stevie Nicks’ Landslide, over a Peta video, the whole country would turn vegan by Monday morning.The miracle of the night, though, was BBC Religion Editor Martin Bashir, who was comfortably worse than both those two and sang like he’d been grabbed nuts-first backstage by Vinnie Jones, yet still got saved by Cowell and Nicole Scherzinger ahead of an understandably inconsolable Olivia Olson.The explanation, I think, lies in the fact Martin brings the precious gt of comedy to X Factor: Celebrity, hopping and skipping across the stage, in his Harold Lloyd get-up, to an old Bert Kaempfert classic.It presented a critical problem, though, for the clearly smitten Cowell, who’d been on the verge of saying the wrong thing all night, but provided the perfect assist on this occasion.“If you recognise that song . . .”Then seriously well done and Danke Schoen, Martin.TV GOLD: Will Sharpe’s scene-stealing performance as Rodney the rent boy in BBC’s engrossing drama Giri Haji.The albatross chick hauling itself back on to a nest and a penguin seal stand-off, from BBC’s Seven Worlds, One Planet. Richard  Judy playing It’s Behind Youon Friday’s This Morning.I don’t half miss that country.Emailed in by Kaz M. Picture research: Amy Reading.GREAT Sporting Insights. Jamie Carragher: “Without looking in the past, Liverpool’s front three have never done anything at this ground.”Stuart Pearce: “They are talking the talk and delivering the delivery.”Matt Dawson: “It’s not necessarily the end of a Welsh era, but let’s face it, it is.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. seven-year-old nephew Gustavo, after he fought to save his mothers le.The adolescent is accused of carrying out the barbaric crimes with the help of a -year-old boy.He is said to be the son of Catia Rabelo, named by police as the -year-old woman charged with masterminding the ruthless plan in a bid to keep the baby for herself.She was arrested by cops on Wednesday after going on the run and has allegedly confessed to inciting the teenagers to commit the brutal killings.Police found the newborn boy alive and in the care of the teenage accomplice at his familys home in Porto Velho, north Brazil.His mother, who was not present when the two were killed, had already fled the scene.The infant, weighing .lbsis currently under observation at Porto Base Old Hospital and is reported to be in title: brexit new year christmas election majority
story: The PMs spokesperson confirmed plans for Parliament to sit the week after the planned election vote - from the  December onwards.An election is now set to take place on December , giving the PM a few days to sort out his Cabinet and get everything ready to open Parliament again.Then there could be several days before Christmas for the PM to try and push through his Brexit Bill againhe wants to.That might leave even more time for debate on the Bill than Boris promised MPs this month.If he wins an election Boris will desperate to press Brexit through as soon as possible.But that will all depend on whether the PM will be able to win the upcoming poll and secure enough MPs to push it through.It comes as:Boris might be flying high in the polls at the moment but that could all change in an election campaign.He may be punished by voters for failing to deliver on his promise to get Britain out of the EU by October .The Brexit Party will be hot on his heels to snap up votes from people who feel betrayed.EU BOSS Donald Tusk has warned that this third Brexit extension may be the last one as he urged Britain to use the time wisely.The President of the European Council hinted that the bloc might not offer another delay to our EU exit.Last week a huge row broke out as nations like France tried to block a long delay.But eventually they fell in line and backed an extension until January  to try and sort out Brexit.Mr Tusk said tonight: To my British friends.The EU has formally adopted the extension. title: tube driver secrets london underground
story: The train operator spoke of secret toilets for staff, station safety, troublesome passengers and even paranormal experiences.The stories came to light on discussion website Reddit from user TrainOperator who was bombarded with hundreds of questions for curious punters.TrainOperator confirmed he had seen paranormal activity in the tunnels during his shts but did not elaborate on the spooky encountersHe revealed one homeless commuter relieved himself right in front of him once.The driver, when asked who the most dficult passenger he ever dealt with was, said: “A vagrant who when asked to leave took a dump on the floor of the train.”He also joked that he now hates the phrase “Mind the Gap” because its “burned into his brain” after years of working on the underground.But he heaped praise on his job and revealed there are secret toilets for drivers dotted around London’s tube stations.TrainOperator said: “The money is good, the benefits are good.“Honestly the best part of my job is that I dont need to take anything home and actually have a real work-le balance.“I stable my train in the depot, or hand it over to another driver, and I just go home.“There is nothing to worry about when Im at home like deadlines or meetings, no one calls or emails me on my time off. I literally just come in, drive my train, go home like people used to do.“My job before TfL involved long hours and having to answer emails and whatnot when I wasnt at work. Being able to switch off is the best part of this job.”He was also asked about TfL’s application process for tube driver.He said: “You need to join the Underground and apply internally, as with all good jobs in the Underground.“You used to be able to apply externally for night tube train operator then transfer to full time, but night tube train op is so popular internally now that their latest campaign is internal only.”Another curious punter asked how drivers get to workthe tube is closed, to which he replied: “There is a network of shuttle taxis that stop at every station that ferry all operational staff around when the trains arent running.”He also shared his sht pattern, with a tube driver from Vienna and another from the US sharing their work routine.And in terms of pay, he told: “Depending on your tax situation and whether you have a student loan, etc you will clear £,-£, every  weeks after tax, pension, etc.”

title: brit couple kicked off ba flight lose 300 compo
story: Mum-of-one Victoria Parker and Paul Dempsey, , were thrown off the plane for being “drunk and disruptive” as they made their way home last month.BA say staff believed the couple were boozed-up after complaints from other passengers about their behaviour.The -year-old hairdresser admitted she was “a bit squfy” and was told she wouldnt be served any more alcohol after a “couple of glasses of wine and an ouzo”.After complaining about their treatment, the couple were sent two voucher codes each worth £ and an “apology”.But raging Victoria continued to complain after being forced to fork out £ for a new flight for her hubby and son.BA probed the issue and realised that the £ vouchers and apology had been sent BY MISTAKE.The immediately withdrew the vouchers and the sorry and have now backed their staff for booting off the couple, saying it was the “appropriate action” as “disruptive behaviour will not be tolerated”.Victoria, from Peterborough, Cambs, said: I dont believe what they are saying, it is totally outrageous and none of it makes sense.BA [called] to say the vouchers were no longer valid and the real reason we were kicked off the plane was because we were both disruptive.[They said theyd] had a complaint that I wasnt actually fit to fly, whereas at the airport it was because I touched someones arm.They are back tracking. Why was I cleared through securityI was a disruption  Why has it gone from me touching a mans arm to us both being complained about.I dont care about the vouchers. Its the way we were treated.I accept I was a bit squfy after three drinks sat in the sun, but I was not in anyway disruptive.And why would they apologise and offer vouchers in the first placewe were those things Victoria and Paul had been sat on the plane on the runway for  minutes before a member of staff approached and asked them to follow him.She claims it “all happened so quickly” and before they knew it, they were being handed their luggage and told they would have to “get a flight tomorrow”.Victoria said: I was very shocked and it all happened so quickly.Victoria and Paul, an engineer, had enjoyed a week away but claim the experience ruined their happy memories.Victoria said: It really spoiled the holiday. We went to Naxos and had a lovely week, but on the way back we arrived at the airport a couple of hours before the plane was due to depart.We went to the bar and I had a few drinks. Paul wasnt drinking at all because he was driving back from Heathrow.I only had a couple of glasses of wine and an ouzo before getting on the plane.We had to pay for another night in a hotel and flights which came to around £. Thats £ that we hadnt budgeted for. If we didnt pay it, wed have been stuck there.They have replied and offered us only £ [each] and no explanation.A spokesperson from British Airways said: Disruptive behaviour will not be tolerated on board our aircraft and we will always take the appropriate action. Unfortunately this email was sent in error and we have been in contact with our customer to explain this.Lorna Lucas, , and husband Clive, , helped strap Chloe Haines, , to her seat after she allegedly stormed the cockpit and screamed “I’m going to kill everyone”.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Boris Johnson took one step closer to a pre-Christmas general election after MPs backed his demands to go to the country in an attempt to end the Brexit deadlock.The Commons voted by  to  at third reading to approve the one-page Bill enabling the election to be held on December .Earlier, MPs voted by  to  to reject a Labour amendment for the proposed polling day to be moved to December  - three days earlier than ministers wanted.The vote effectively clears the way for Parliament to be dissolved on November , paving the way for an election on December .But what happens now. What happens now in Parliament  MPs have backed the bill, but the House of Lords need to debate it before it can become law. It will be presented to the Lords tonight ahead of scrutiny beginning tomorrow morning. If Peers make any changes, it will move back and forth between the Lord and Commons on Thursday, until it is finally approved. It is expected to be given Royal Assent by the Queen on Thursday. MPs will also debate a bill to continue funding Northern Irelandaposs public services, and the findings of the report into the Grenfell Fire. Will Boris Johnson try and bring back his Withdrawal Agreement Bill Jacob Rees-Mogg has said the government will not reintroduce the bill.Meaning the final judgement on Mr Johnsonaposs bill will be made by the next Parliament.    When will Parliament be dissolved  Parliament is due to be dissolved at a minute past midnight next Wednesday - November th - firing the starting gun on five-and-a-half weeks of intense campaigning. When does the campaign begin  Parliament will break up on Wednesday November . This is when what’s called the “short campaign” begins. There are strict spending restrictions for political parties during that time. But from now everything the main parties say will have the election in mind. Will there be a TV leadersapos debate  We donapost know yet.Broadcasters have always been keen on TV head-to-heads, but Conservative politicians - especially Boris Johnson - less so.   When is the deadline to register to vote  If an election is on Thursday  December, the deadline to register to vote is likely to be at midnight on Monday  November. The deadline for new postal vote applications, or changes to existing postal votes, is likely to be pm on Tuesday  November. The deadline for receiving new proxy vote applicationswill be pm on Friday  December. The deadline for applying for an emergency proxy vote -you are suddenly ill for example - is pm on polling day. Who needs to register  If you have never voted, have moved constituency or have turned  recently then you will need to registeryou have not done so already. You can even get yourself on the registeryou are  or  but you will need to have turned  before the election date to actually be eligible to vote.    Who is eligible to vote  All those who are  or over on the day of the election and are a British, Irish or qualying Commonwealth citizen. Eligible voters must be resident at an address in the UK . Prisoners are not allowed to vote.

Labour swung behind Boris Johnsonaposs bid for a general election in December - the first one since .Whoever wins will steer Britainaposs policy on leaving the EU for years to come, and their first days in office will be crucial deciding what happens next. Boris Johnson and Labour have radically dferent approaches. So what will happen to Brexiteither of them get into power  Hereaposs a basic explanation.  Nope. Well not exactly.Thedealis still active and agreed between the UK, the EU and  European leaders - so it can be taken up by whoever gets into  Downing Street, Labour or Tory. But theBillthat puts it into law will be parked until after an election, when itaposd have to be brought back to the UK Parliament from scratch. Itaposll be easy to bring the Withdrawal Agreement Bill back and pass itBoris Johnson wins a majority.If he doesnapost get a majority itaposs a dferent story. So the PM is gambling it all on winning the house.  Boris Johnson would have achieved his goal of clearing opposition to his Brexit plan. He could bring back his Withdrawal Agreement Bill and, this time, get it through the House of Commons without it being whittled down by angry MPs. No doubt he would still face opposition, buthe had an overall majority - of MPs buoyed by an election victory - heaposd likely be able to get it through the Commons before the January  deadline. There could still be a hold-up when the Bill got to the Lords, and the European Parliament, which both need to raty it. But the path would be easier. If he still faced opposition, Mr Johnson has not ruled out leaving with no deal at the end of January.  Labour has vowed to try to negotiate its own, softer Brexit deal - one that protects workersapos rights, has alignment with the single market and puts the UK in a customs union with Brussels.You could expect to see Jeremy Corbyn going to Brussels in a bid to reopen talks with EU chiefs.Brussels leaders have previously been reluctant to do this, but a change of leadership in the UK would be a clear incentive to reopen negotiations. Whatever Labour come up with, that would then be put back to the people in a confirmatory second referendum. Itaposs likely people would be asked to choose between Remain and the Labour deal. Labour would only decide how to campaign in that referendum at some point in  at a special conference. All this would almost certainly require another delay to Brexit. What happensthe Lib Dems get a majorityThis would be unprecedented but... theyaposve said theyaposd revoke Article  . The Lib Dems also back a second referendum. We know you hate to hear it, but... probably more of the same. How Brexit unfolds will be defined by what groupings can be formed between Remainers - including small parties like the Lib Dems, who are widely expected to make gains - and Brexiteers. Expect more running battles, attempts by backbenchers to delay Brexit, or a surprising majority around one thing or the other. A hung Parliament could boost calls for a second referendum, because some would see it as the only way out now an election has been exhausted. But whether enough MPs would back it for it to actually happen, through a vote in Parliament, is a totally dferent matter. Boris Johnson finally agreed a Brexit deal with the EU on  October , though it still needs approval by MPs and is now on ice. The -page list of amendments keeps a transition period up to  December  and the £bn orce bill. But it scraps the Irish backstop, an insurance policy designed at preventing a hard border between Northern Ireland the Republic. In the backstopaposs place would effectively be apostwo bordersapos in a hybrid system:Northern Ireland and Britain would share a legal customs territory - technically forcing customs checks on goods crossing the -mile border with the Republic. But in practice, to avoid checks at the border, the checks will instead happen when goods reach Northern Ireland on the island of Ireland. Critics say this puts a customs border across the Irish Sea - more of this below.  Northern Ireland and the Republic would share some EU single market rules - forcing checks on manufactured and agricultural products crossing the Irish Sea.The Northern Ireland Assembly - known as Stormont - will get a vote every four years on whether to let EU law continue. Hamza Ul Haq, , Loic Nengese, , and a -year-old boy allegedly murdered Joseph William-Torres, , in the belief he was Samuel Hunter. Mr Torres was blasted at point-blank range in the chest on March , . Jurors at the Old Bailey heard the man was ambushed by three men associated with an east London gang known as the of the Mali crew. The attack, which lasted  seconds in Walthamstow, northeast London, killed Mr Torres. It is said the three men were intent on a revenge attack after Ul Haq had been squirted with acid and his friend was stabbed by masked youths in a Subway shop some months previously.  They had, it would appear, mistakenly identied him for another: Samuel Hunter. Samuel Hunter is a male of the same height, same build, similar facial features, who even possessed and wore the same beanie hat as Joseph William Torres, who lived locally and often socialised in Essex Close with and where members of Priory Court used to meet, Alison Hunter, QC, prosecuting, said. Ul Haq, of Manor Park, east London, Nengese of Walthamstow, and the youth from Upper Clapton, all deny murder. But the court heard the attack was planned. Ms Hunter continued: It was undoubtedly a ruthless and planned attack on a rival group member, but he was not the intended target. The explanation perhaps lies in the fact that this shooting was not an isolated incident - rather it took place in the context of what can be characterised as a series of related and retaliatory acts of violence that had at its roots, a dispute between rival groups of youths.

story: NewsHomeowner very lucky after chunk of warplane lands in garden with loud thudA large metal chunk from an American B- bomber landed in the propertys garden in Brailes, WarwickshireShareCommentsByEd Chatterton:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsA B- bomber lands at RAF Fairford in Gloucestershire "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. The unidentied woman contacted police after hearing a loud thud outside her property in Brailes, Warks., at around .pm last Wednesday. The villager went into outside and discovered the piece had broken from the fighter plane and landed in her front garden, narrowly missing her home. The homeowner, who wished to remain anonymous, said: All I heard was this strange loud noise, kind of like an unusual bump sort of sound. You wonapost find any evidence in the front garden where it landed, we managed to get it back to normal pretty quickly.    Iaposve been contacted by the police and even the MOD. We are on a flight path here but you never expect something like this to happen. Itaposs a miracle that it landed in the garden on not on me in the house. Iaposm very lucky in that regard. Aviation experts attended the scene and confirmed the debris was part of a giant B- bomber which had been based in the county at RAF Fairford, Glos. Warwickshire Police shared the details of the shocking incident on social media with a picture of the yellow metal casing from the US Air Force war plane. PCSO Emma Turner and PCSO Fin Moore, from Shipston Police Safer Neighbourhood Team, said: Yesterday around .pm in Brailes a resident reported hearing a thud in her front garden on closer inspection she discovered what appeared to be a small part from an aircraft. We attended and Aviation and relevant Authorities were informed.Its a part from a US B Bomber from Fairford Glos. They have been in contact. It is unclear which part of the plane it has come from, but it believed it could be part of the engine cowling, which covers and cools the engine during take-off and landing. Web users reacted to the bizarre incident on social media and said it was a miracle nobody was hurt and no property was damaged. Ian Bright said: Considering what could have fallen off a B, think they got away lightly. Mel Harris added: That is extremely dangerous. Its a miracle nobody was badly hurt or killed and so lucky it missed all the houses. RAF Fairford is a temporary military base for the B-s, which were used by the USAF Air Force since  and featured in the Cold War, Vietnam War and the Gulf War. They are part of a deployment of four from Barksdale Air Force Base in Louisiana, a southeastern U.S. state on the Gulf of Mexico. They have been in Britain for the past few weeks as part of Bomber Task Force Europe, an American show of military strength and support in Europe. When they arrived in March it was the largest US bomber deployment to the UK since the Iraq war. The Boeing B- is one of the largest war planes used by the USAF, it carries up to , pounds of weapons and cost around million each.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A lying bride-to-be who fleeced her fiance and his  closest pals by stealing their Ibiza stag party cash has avoided jail.Stunned Chris Mahone only realised “deceitful and callous” Rachel Doran had ripped them off as they got ready for take off. The unsuspecting stag party discovered their flight tickets from Leeds Bradford airport were all fake. With rising panic the stags called ahead to the Ibiza Rocks hotel on the party isle and found that no bookings had been made. Nuclear process worker Chris, , realised with horror that while they had been planning their wedding, his fiance had secretly been spending the £, stag do cash on herself.    When he rang from the airport to ask her what had happened to the cash, Doran told him she was pregnant. But her internet history later revealed she had searched the words fake ultrasound picture maker. Doran, , fled the home they shared in Cleator Moor, Cumbria, when Chris told her the wedding was off and he never wanted to see her again.Doran avoided prison at Carlisle crown court on Tuesday after she admitted stealing from the stag party and forging Jet flight documents.   The court was told that Doran and Mr Mahone were childhood friends who had met at school, later starting a relationship. Their wedding date was set for December  and the groom had planned a three day stag party for September. Doran was made the treasurer for the stag do and helped organise it along with two of Mr Mahoneaposs best friends. She collected £ from each of the stags and was supposed to bank it to pay for their flights and hotels. Instead she frittered it away on herself and online gambling sites.  Gerard Rogerson, prosecuting, told the court the stag party met at Cleator Moor Celtic Football Club on September th . They first realised something was wrong when the bus failed to turn up to take them to the airport. They persuaded the bus company there had been a mistake and a driver came out to take them to Leeds Bradford. Mr Rogerson said: A member of the group had got there before the bus and said there was a problem, his documents had not been recognised and this cast doubt on the entire booking arrangement. He rang the Ibiza Rocks Hotel and discovered that no bookings had been made. It became clear the Jet booking confirmation form was a fake document and it was then that Mr Mahone tried to ring Miss Doran on her mobile phone but she did not answer initially. Later in the day Miss Doran phoned him wanting to talk and he told her to leave him alone as he wanted nothing to do with her. She texted him later and told him she was pregnant.  A victim impact statement from Mr Mahone said: I felt so let down. I trusted her and was getting ready to settle down and spend the rest of my le with her. I loved her at the time and I have not been able to move on because I cannot trust anyone  in the way I trusted Rachel. I am trying to move on but I find it dficult to talk to women because I am scared of getting hurt. My friends are gutted, they donapost want the money back, they just want justice done. “My friends could have turned on me but they didnapost. story: NewsMan who had routine hernia operation died after suffering a stroke the next dayAn inquest heard how a consultant believed the timing of Peter Heards stroke to be a coincidence and felt the surgery did not play a part - however a coroner did describe the timing as suspiciousShareCommentsByLee Trewhela:,  OCT NewsPeter Heard died at Derrord Hospital, Plymouth"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who underwent a routine hernia operation tragically died after suffering a stroke the following day.An inquest was told the timing of -year-old Peter Heardaposs stroke was a coincidence - although it was also described as apossuspiciousapos.Despite the family’s solicitor requesting a narrative verdict, the coroner concluded that Mr Heard died from natural causes. But his widow Anne Heard, of Ottery St Mary in Devon, told coroner Andrew Cox that she did not want his sympathy concerning her late husband.She then walked out of the inquest into his death while declaring “I will take this matter further,” according to Devon Live.The inquest in Truro, where Devon coroner Mr Cox is now overseeing cases, heard today that Mr Heard, a fit and active man, had elective surgery on a hernia at Heavitree Hospital in Exeter on July , .His blood pressure at the time of the operation was well within the safe limit and was checked before, during and after the procedure.All risks associated with the routine operation were described to Mr Heard, although not any risk of death which was believed to be too small. He was reassured and happy to proceed.    The procedure went smoothly and the anaesthetist was happy that nothing occurred which could have played a part in his stroke the next day. The inquest heard that Mr Heard was keen tohome and sleep in his own bed. In the early morning of the next day he was found collapsed downstairs in his home. He was admitted to the Royal Devon and Exeter Hospital suffering from a stroke. It was decided that in his best interests he should be transferred to Derrord Hospital in Plymouth where a thrombectomy would be performed to retrieve a clot from his brain. Unfortunately, the procedure was not successful and the operation was terminated. Over the next few days he was no longer able to respond with his eyes or verbally, and his braindeteriorated. He died on July . Mr Cox read a statement from Mr Heard’s son Daniel which questioned whether the hernia operation caused or contributed to the clot which killed his father. Consultant Mr Ivaylo Tzvetkov said that only one in , patients suffer such a complication following a hernia operation. He believed the timing was a coincidence and felt the surgery did not play a part in the clot developing. Pathologist Dr David Hilton was unable to saythe procedure was a factor, but in  years’ experience as a consultant he had never seen a previous case where a hernia operation had caused a stroke. However, he did say that the timing was suspicious.

title: two teens who fist bumped
story: NewsTwo teens who fist-bumped after stabbing boxer to death are jailed for  yearsWilham Mendes, , was chased into an alleyway and repeatedly kned by one of a gang of four robbers in Tottenham, north LondonShareByLuke OReilly:,  OCT NewsWilham Mendes was a keen amateur boxer "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo teenage killers who fist bumped in celebration after stabbing an amateur boxer to death have been jailed for a total of  and a half years. Wilham Mendes, , was walking home from his job as a kitchen porter when he was chased into an alleyway. He was repeatedly kned by one of a gang of four robbers during a night of crime outside McDonaldaposs in Tottenham, north London. They targeted the keen boxer minutes after another mugging by a bus stop on Tottenham High Road on December  last year. Mr Mendes was stopped by the teenagers near Bruce Grove railway station shortly after am on December  last year. The Portuguese national tried to run off but his bag was taken and he was stabbed repeatedly in the alley. After the murder CCTV footage captured his -year-old killer wiping the bloodied blade on his clothes before aposfist-bumpingapos his -year-old accomplice as they all aposcalmly jogged awayapos. The -year-old admitted murder part-way through his trial at the Old Bailey and the -year-old admitted manslaughter. Both were convicted of robbing Mr Mendes.  Another -year-old and a boy who was  at the time but is now also  were cleared of murder but found guilty of robbery along with the older boy. The older boy and another -year-old admitted mugging another man, for which the other two were acquitted, and all four were further cleared of attempting to rob a third victim. The court heard all the teenagers have previous convictions for kne crime and the -year-old has been robbing victims since he was . He was even caught with a homemade kne in a young offenders centre when he was serving  months for a robbery at the point of a machete in Ipswich and was on licence when he killed Mr Mendes. Eleven security guards crammed into the dock as the robbers were sentenced including four in full riot gear who surrounded the -year-old. Judge Angela Rafferty ordered the -year-old to serve a minimum of  and a half years at Her Majestyaposs Pleasure and the  year-old was ordered to serve ten years. You all knew a robbery was to take place and you all joined in, the judge said. Within a short time of this robbery Mr Mendes was dying in an alleyway. The judge added: It is clear that his loving family were on his mind at the end of his le. The judge said the murder was brutal and senseless. Turning to the two killers she said: The jury watched you fist bump. I am satisfied this was validation and a degree of celebration of what had taken place. The second -year-old was given two and a half years but the last -year-old walked free with a two year youth rehabilitation order. The -year-old could be heard screaming and banging doors as he was led to the cells. Jurors heard two friends, Amari Lawson and Hayden Potter, were standing outside McDonaldaposs when they were approached by the four teenagers. Mr Lawson fled and was pursued by two of them while the other pair stayed with Mr Potter. Mr Potter managed to escape with his belongings but Mr Lawsonaposs bag was taken. Oliver Glasgow QC, prosecuting, said: Wilham Mendes was on his way home from work. He tried to escape. His bag was taken from him and he was chased into an alleyway where he was stabbed several times. He bled to death in the alley. He added: The -year-old and one of the -year-olds can be seen to bump fists in celebration.

story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Its time for us to ditch this lame-duck Prime MinisterThis will be a chance for the nation to vote not just on Brexit, but on a decade of Tory austerityShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  OCT NewsopinionCocky PM Boris Johnson deserves to disappear into his infamous ditch. "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson may believe he is leading us into a Brexit general election. But elections are rarely about what those contesting them might choose. For this will be an opportunity for the nation to vote not just on Brexit but on a decade of Tory austerity and unnecessary hardship, of inequality and on a lame-duck Prime Minister. And going to the polls in winter, when our NHS is already buckling under the strain, may mean the real issues of this country quickly rise up the agenda. Yet evenwe look at the election on Johnson’s narrow terms, he enters the contest as a dud – the Tory PM who vowed to deliver Brexit by October , and failed.    So he deserves to disappear into his ­infamous ditch. December  now offers a glorious opportunity to boot jaundiced Johnson and his austerity Tories out of high office and put Jeremy Corbyn in to No .Above all , this is a chance to vote for positive change over the next five years, to vote for a £ minimum wage, decent public serv-ices and everything  in Labour’s transformative programme.Cocky Johnson may lead in the polls but he should recall the wise warning from past Tory premier Harold Macmillan about fearing “events”, and Labour’s Harold Wilson’s observation that a week is a long time in politics.

story: NewsTerried workers swap name tags to try stop stalking and sexual harassmentThe Australian Human Rights Commission looked at how prevalent sexual harassment directed at shop staff wasShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsShop workers have told of their bad experiences at the hands of customers "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Women working in retail in Australia have spoken candidly about the treatment they receive while working on the shop floor. Nyakim Nyuon has been employed in the fast food industry for three years. The -year-old told the Sydney Morning Herald how she had been filmed without her consent by flirtatious customers. Two of her co-workers swapped name tags after a visitor to the shop began stalking a colleague. In the end she started wearing a tag with a fake name on it in the hope that the overreaching customer would be dettered.   An anonymous respondent to the Australian Human Rights Commission survey on sexual harassment said: Wearing a badge with our name on it makes customers and sexual predators feel comfortable enough to harass us under the guise of friendliness.It also allows them to think that because they know your name they are entitled to other personal information about you and to touch you. Wearing a name badge also makes it incredibly easy for those same predators to go home and look us up online and then harass us from the comfort of their homes.” The research found that % of , retail, fast food and warehouse workers surveyed in Australia had experienced some kind of sexual harassment in the past five years. Another woman spoke of a man slow moving closer to her as she worked in a restaurant. “My harasser sits outside my work in the food court and watches me as I work, she said. title: blether near complete footballer left dens to join neighbours united
story: Senior players moving “across the road” in Dundee are relatively few and far between.There have been glaring examples over the years such as Tommy Coyne, Ian Phillip and others.Bobby Robinson leaving Dens Park was a big disappointment to me.I thought he was a near complete footballer who just didn’t seem to have a bad game.As a Dundee fan, his transfer to city rivals United left a sour taste.I can’t remember the reasons given at the time, so I looked up cuttings of that era.The cutting was dated August , , and, indeed, mentioned it as a “surprise swop deal”.Robinson signed for Jim McLean’s Tangerines, while Billy Williamson left Tannadice to sign up at Dens Park.There was “a modest cash fee adjustment in Dundee’s favour”.Robinson had joined Dundee from Falkirk, and had been six years a dark blue.Williamson’s time at Tannadice was less than six months, Jim McLean having signed him from Aberdeen for a £, fee. His game time amounted to just seven games for United.The cutting also revealed that, earlier that year, Dundee wanted to sign Williamson from Aberdeen while trying to offload Robinson to Hearts.Robinson, who had one cap for Scotland, refused that move, so the move for Williamson at that time stalled as the Dens Parkers were planning on using the fee from Hearts to fund the move.Footnote – I use the word ‘Footnote’ as at the bottom of the aforementioned cutting it was titled thus.It had nothing to do with the above-mentioned players but informed readers that a young Dundee United player, Alan Boath, had left Tannadice and moved to Forfar Athletic.I relay this tale simply because Alan has been very supportive of this column and has contributed on a few occasions.Alan emigrated to New Zealand not long after and enjoyed a long and great career over there.He represented NZ in the  World Cup in Spain, where one of his opponents was Scotland.

title: dundee united 2 0 dunfermline clark comes back to haunt pars as utd stay top
story: Nicky Clark turned in a man-of-the-match display against his former team Dunfermline to help Dundee United to a vital - win and cement their place at the top of the table.The former Pars hitman teed up Lawrence Shankland for the opener on nine minutes before curling in a tremendous free-kick on  minutes to win the Tangerines all three points and keep top spot in the Championship outright.United manager Robbie Neilson made three changes from the - defeat at Queen of the South with Jamie Robson, Peter Pawlett and Clark coming in for Paul Watson, Sam Stanton and Louis Appere.Unbeaten in their last four, Dunfermline only showed one dference to their starting XI with Andy Ryan coming in for Kevin Nisbet for the Tannadice clash.And it was United who started strongest as they took the lead on nine minutes.Liam Smith#s initial delivery from the right caused Cammy Gill in the Pars goal to flap at the ball and when Clark launched it back into the box, Shankland made no mistake from six yards out to net his th United goal of the season.Two minutes later Dunfermline threatened to net a quick equaliser but Benjamin Siegrist in the home goal was a match for Ryan#s header. On  minutes, the Pars had another chance to draw level but Kyle Turner blasted over from  yards.However, it was former Par Clark who came back to haunt his old side three minutes later as the Terrors doubled their lead.After Ian Harkes was fouled on the edge of the box, Clark smashed home his first of the season with a curling right-footed free-kick from  yards out leaving Gill rooted to the spot.Paul McMullan nearly made it - on  minutes, sliding onto Smith#s low delivery at the front post, but Dunfermline managed to clear the danger.Three minutes after the restart Calum Butcher rled a full volley just over the bar from  yards after the ball broke kindly for the Englishman.Having only just ed from injury there was concern over Robson on  minutes when he went down in his own box but after receiving treatment he was OK to continue.On  minutes the Fers had their best chance of the match as Josh Edwards slid in former Terror Ryan Dow but Siegrist got down well to deny the attacker from close in.The home side bounced back, though, as Clark was denied a double by a well-timed Lee Ashcroft block in the box following Pawlett#s cutback.Second-half sub Nisbet threatened to claw one back for Stevie Crawford#s men but his volley into the ground bounced over on  minutes.On  minutes Dunfermline came even closer, this time Nisbet feeding Ryan who cracked a curling effort off the crossbar.United were able to close out the final moments, despite heavy pressure from the visitors, to snap a two-game losing streak and tighten their grip on top spot.With Ayr United losing to Dundee on Friday night and Inverness falling to Morton, the Terrors move three points clear at the Championship summit.Dundee United : SiegristSmith, Robson, Reynolds , Brown Butcher , Harkes McMullan, Pawlett , ClarkShankland.Subs not used: Deniz , Sporle, Stanton, Watson.Dunfermline : GillComrie, Edwards, Martin , Ashcroft Paton, Cochrane , Turner , Dow Kiltie, Ryan.Subs not used: Scully , Beadling, Morrison, Coley.Ref: Steven Reid.Att: ,.

title: sleeping giant is ready to awaken says dundee united coach lee mcculloch
story: Assistant boss Lee McCulloch says results like the - loss at Queen of the South show Dundee United are miles away from where they want to be – but he insists they are getting closer week by week.McCulloch, boss Robbie Neilson and fellow-assistant Gordon Forrest all put pen to paper on contract extensions to  last week.The coaching team have been given the target of finally getting the Tangerines back to the top flight this season.The former Scotland international says the club’s home form this campaign shows they have the ability to do that, starting this weekend as they welcome Dunfermline to Tannadice.The Tangerines will defend their % record on home turf in the Championship against the Pars aiming to add to the impressive  goals they’ve scored in just four matches.He told the Tele: “We spoke pre-season about making Tannadice a fortress again and a hard place to come.“The only way we will do that is to win games and then, with that, hopefully, the fans come back.“When they do that it is a very intimidating place to play football for any away team.“The only way is to win football games and we have done that at home this season.“We are getting there, we’re not where we want to be, miles off, but we have a vision.“Hopefully, it all goes to plan and we get promotion this year.“As long as we entertain fans then they’ll turn up for matchdays.“The detail that goes into training and the effort is brilliant.“The standard has been raised, even from last season.“We want to keep the momentum of that going and play attractive football. Hopefully, we can then give them something to shout about come the end of the season.”McCulloch says it didn’t take long to consider whether he wanted to extend his stay at the club for another two-and-a-half years alongside Robbie and fellow- assistant Gordon Forrest.“It’s great to have it all signed last week,” said McCulloch.“I’m delighted to be at Dundee United and it’s great to be working alongsideTony Asghar as well as Robbie and Gordon on a daily basis.“It wasn’t a dficult decision to extend my stay here, I know the size of the club and I still see it as a sleeping giant, even though we are sitting at the top of the league.“I think we have a Premiership team and a top-six club, no problem at all, with the history and following the club has. How can you not enjoy working in an establishment like this ”McCulloch added: “Tony came in and addressed how he wanted to change the culture and environment at the club alongside the manager.“I think they have done that and myself and Gordon Forrest, as assistants, are here to help with that.“That comes from the recruitment of players, from training every day and standards around the training ground and Tannadice.“I think we have done pretty well with that and training every day is conducted to a high standard.“It’s also about bringing that learning culture to the place, especially for the young players.“The manager loves to put youth in the first team which he has shown with Chris Mochrie, Louis Appere, Logan Chalmers and lots of others.“At Dundee United, it’s not about age, it’s aboutyou’re good enough then you’ll play first team.“I think that only adds to us getting Dundee United back on the footballing map.”

title: sneak glimpse as revamped gallery set to rival va
story: Aberdeen’s revamped Art Gallery will rival Dundee’s VA museum, the city council’s co-leader has claimed ahead of its reopening this weekend.The Evening Express got a sneak glimpse inside the completed venue yesterday, which has been undergoing a £. million revamp since .Aberdeen City Council co-leader Jenny Laing claimed the new tourist attraction would rival the VA design museum in Dundee and other regional galleries across the country.Speaking after the tour, which saw media guided around the three floors of revamped space, Ms Laing said: “The new art gallery is going to blow people away.“They’re going to understand why it was important for our city centre regeneration that we spend money on this project.“I definitely think it will rival the VA. The quality of the collections we have in Aberdeen, it needs a building to showcase it.”The revamped gallery, which has been hit by delays since closing its doors, will also go some way to helping the city “ersy” its economy, the council co-leader claimed.She said: “It was important to us that we made sure we provided a world-class visitor attraction that will attract not just local people but tourists from far and wide.“It’s always been our intention to make sure the redevelopment is a world-class facility.“I think that’s what we have achieved, it’s taken a bit of time but I think with the age and complexity of the project it was important we made sure we got everything right.” vw, px"  Douglas Lumsden, who co-leads the local authority alongside Ms Laing, claimed the gallery rivals any regional gallery he has seen where.He added: “The collection we have is absolutely fantastic and we can now exhibit three times more than we could, we’ve gone up from  gallery spaces to .“We can show off a lot more and I think we’ve got a fitting gallery to host the collection we have.”The redevelopment has dramatically increased the amount of display space for the city’s nationally-recognised collection, with the number of galleries increasing from  to  and the number of items on display increasing from  to ,.Among the changes are the construction of a whole new top floor, which museum bosses say will be a “game changer”, offering “new vistas” across the city.The Remembrance Hall has also been revamped and now includes new digital rolls of honour. vw, px"  These will scroll continuously on the wall of the hall, showing the names of everyone recorded in the city’s Book of Remembrance.Technology has been introduced across the buildings, with digital touchscreens providing more information on many of the works.Meanwhile, new LED lighting has been installed in the roof of some of the gallery space, which gives the impression of natural light and can be changed as the seasons change.Aberdeen City Council has pledged £.m from capital funds, and the National Lottery Heritage Fund has made a £m contribution but the council is still £.m short of its £m public fundraising target.Oil firm BP has donated £m to go towards its gallery space and £.m has been given by the UK Government to support the Remembrance Hall renovations.The ongoing public fundraising campaign will continue, with Mr Lumsden claiming he thinks visitors will be inspired to donate to the project once they get inside this weekend. vw, px"  He said: “My feeling is now the gallery is open this weekend, once people come and visit, I think people will contribute to the gallery we’ve built here.“There’s still a dispute ongoing with the main contractor and that dispute will continue and we’re trying to minimise the cost to the council as much as possible.”Councillor Alex Nicoll, SNP resource spokesman, said: “The city has been robbed of its Art Gallery for far too long so I’m delighted that it will be open again very soon.“Sadly, this is not the end of the story as the administration still need to tell us how much money this project has actually cost the people of Aberdeen.”The first members of the public will get access to the gallery this weekend but tickets have sold out for the event.More than , free tickets were snapped up within hours of being released last month, with timed slots in place to ensure the best experience for visitors.From Monday, regular opening times will be am to pm Monday to Saturday and Sunday from am to pm, with free admission.

title: letters to the editor september 6 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsDear Mr O#Hara,I write to you regarding your recent undated, round-robin constituency letter and its misleading, generalising and obviously politically biased contents.This is to mention nothing of its scaremongering phraseology and use of expressions such as #crash out# of Europe.Are you seriously suggesting thatwe do not always agree with the Germans that they would stop buying our whisky, fish and tweeds  Or are they not wishing to sell their cars and wine to us  Or visit us as holiday-makers I think not.Your party political bias is only too obvious and you should remember that while you were voted in as MP, it was only by a minority of Argyll and Bute residents, and certainly not by the majority of us.In your snide comments about Boris Johnston # of whom I, too, am not a fan # you give not a single example to back up your contention that he is #causing serious economic and social harm to both Argyll and Bute and Scotland as a whole#.While no-one expects the truth from politicians in general, we do actually expect it at a local level.R Henderson, LochgilpheadSir,The Scottish SPCA is urging the people of Scotland to share their stories, photos and memories of the charity as it prepares to celebrate its th birthday.Set up with the goal of aiding overworked horses and ponies in Leith, Scotland’s animal welfare charity was founded on  December .The Scottish SPCA now has nine animal rescue and rehoming centres and a world-leading wildle hospital in Clackmannanshire. Last year, it rehomed over , domestic pets and successfully released , wild animals back to their natural environment. The society now also delivers industry-leading animal welfare educational programmes to people of all ages.In my short time with the society I know of hundreds of examples of our dedicated people going above and beyond to do all they can for the animals and humans they come across. So, I can only imagine how many fantastic stories must be out there about the people who’ve worn our unorm since we were formed.As well as those who have had a positive experience with us in the recent past, we are hoping to uncover some long lost tales from descendants of those we’ve touched in decades gone by.The society wants anyone with any interesting anecdotes or memorabilia to get in touch via the website or by emailing .years@scottishspca.org.Kirsteen Campbell, chief executive, Scottish SPCASir,The likelihood of the UK exiting the EU has now shted from ‘possible’ to ‘probable’.That gives greater focus to our efforts to prepare and proof our farming industry from the impacts of no deal.Whilst it always has been  the position of NFU Scotland that the UK must secure a favourable deal on the terms of exit with the EU, we must also support our industry through any change in the operating environment.Many NFU Scotland members might think that their businesses won’t be impacted, but the reality is that there will be implications for all of us. Some will be direct and immediate, and others more indirect and emerging through time – but the one certainty is that these will be felt by all of us involved in the agri-food chain.There are a few things that would make a big dferenceapplied right across the board in the UK.First, the UK Government’s proposed import tarf schedule desperately requires revision. It would expose some produce # specically cereals, oilseeds, potatoes, eggs and horticultural produce # to a tarf going into the EU, but would allow that same product to come into the UK with no tarf.This is farcical.To apply asymmetrical tarfs on any products between us and the EU is to completely misunderstand the nature of food security in the UK and fails to recognise that trade is vital to both the UK and the EU.One thing that can be done, regardless of Brexit, is for our own governments to prioritise using our own products when it comes to public procurement.All our politicians like to talk about how good our agricultural industry is in comparison to others across the world in terms of standards and environmental benefits, but we don’t see near enough in the way of Scottish or British products being prioritised for use in schools, hospitals and other public services.Yes, it may add one or two pence to a meal – but I would challenge governments and public procurement buyers what the real cost is of bringing products in from other parts of the world.These products certainly don’t meet our standards – not to mention the impact on climate change with food miles taken into consideration.It’s only a couple of years since the kids in our schools were getting their chicken from Thailand. Things are improving, but it’s still not Scottish chicken.This is within the gt of both Holyrood and Westminster, but it might just be the catalyst for governments to work with local authorities to do the right thing when it comes to feeding those who use our public services.Martin Kennedy, vice president, NFU ScotlandSir,I read with interest the letter from Doctor Strain in the August  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser.Might I suggest that to produce a meaningful logo for the GP practices the following criteria are applied:The logo will need to show:May I suggest there are better ways to provide a service to treat patients, without resorting to gimmicks.Name and address supplied.Sir,I was intrigued to read Finlay Craig’s ramblings in last week#s Argyllshire Advertiser.Would he be willing to share the location of his magical bramble bush for it appears the fruits of this bountul bush, when mixed into a pie, contain mystical properties that can transport the diner to another world May I suggest he tries a cold slice of reality pie now and again which would snap him out of his biased reverie and bring him back to the reality of the UK parliament being suspended and the Scottish representative of the party responsible for that outrageous manoeuvre vacating her post in protest In contrast, the Scottish government is working, along with others, to stop Scotland being dragged out of Europe against its wishes. Or perhaps the suspension of democracy is okay in his dream world If Mr Craig or any of his friends eat too much of his prodigious pie, I am sure they will not hesitate to avail themselves of a free prescription for their malaise and, should they need it, free bus travel to the chemist to pick it up, all supplied by the Scottish Government. If they live on one of our beautul islands, they can soon jump on one of the new ferries being completed as I write, again thanks to the Scottish Government.All this aside, when he rejoins us on planet earth, Mr Craig might think of entering his mysterious pie in the baking section of next year#s Mid Argyll Show, though I think by that time we may all be in need of something a little stronger from Scotland’s political larder to extract us from the bitter reality of Brexit Britain.Charles Ambrose, Lochgilphead.Sir,The National Autistic Society wants to find exceptional people, schools and services making a huge dference to autistic children and adults and their families. If readers know anyone like this, please nominate them for our eighth annual Autism Professionals Awards.It could be an inspirational teacher, a brilliant nurse or doctor, a forward-thinking employer or someone who volunteers their time to support others. We want to celebrate their achievements and share their stories so we can promote innovative autism practice and inspire other people and organisations to help create a society that works for autistic people.Find out more about autism and nominate by visiting autismprofessionalsawards.org.ukCarol Povey, director of the National Autistic Society#s Centre for Autism.Sir,When Ruth Davidson resigned as branch manager of the Tories in Scotland, it was as well she did not upset those who were, and will remain, the real bosses # that is, Boris and co at the London head office.Her claim she #wants to spend more time with her family# is the political equivalent of the schoolchild#s pathetic excuse #Please Sir, the dog ate my homework#.David Hay, Minard.Sir,I am thrilled Macmillan Cancer Support’s World Biggest Coffee Morning is fast approaching.I love a cuppa and it is great you can help people with cancer at the same time so I would love readers to get involved.Macmillan’s World Biggest Coffee Morning raises millions for the ever-growing number of people affected by cancer. Macmillan is not government funded, so without the public’s generous help, the charity cannot provide the services needed in Scotland.Around , coffee mornings are held in workplaces, schools and homes across the country every year. It could not be simpler and more fun to take part # come together as a community in support of people living with cancer and raise money for Macmillan.Macmillan is here to help everyone with cancer live le as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. The charity provides advice and support seven days a week on its free support line as well as through its , healthcare professionals.But demand for Macmillan’s services is constantly growing and it needs your help to support the growing number of people living with cancer.Macmillan’s World Biggest Coffee Morning takes place on Friday September  # but people can host whenever they want. People will be making a dference, however they get involved.Whoever you invite and whatever you serve, you can host your coffee morning your way -i f you can’t bake, that doesn’t have to stop you.Readers can find events nearby using the interactive map on www.macmillan.org.uk coffee.Do something amazing and sign up to host a World’s Biggest Coffee Morning at coffeeregister.macmillan.org.uk. Thank you.Martin Clunes

title: letters to the editor september 13 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirI applaud the letter in last week#s issue from Martin Kennedy of NFU Scotland, calling for our governments and public procurement buyers to ensure that they prioritise Scottish food.I would point to the example of #the Preston model#, where the city council has adopted a #guerrilla localism#. It keeps its money as close to home as possible so that, amid historically drastic cuts, the amount spent locally has gone up as featured inon January ,  which notes #where other authorities privatise, Preston grows its own businesses#.Preston ensures that its resources prioritise local providers and businesses wherever possible. Argyll and Bute Council#s Procurement Strategy   falls some way short of this. Its stated aims commendably include:There is no particular emphasis, however, on using its resources to grow Argyll and Bute businesses, to reduce carbon emissions and food transport miles or to foster healthy eating strategies that would benefit our local farmers through #joining up the dots# of local supply and demand.The climate emergency demands a bolder and more innovative respond, and demands it now.Mary MacCallum Sullivan, ArdrishaigSir,I wish to comment on Mr Henderson#s  open letter to Brendan O#Hara in the September  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser.The expression #crash out# of Europe is used by Conservative members of parliament, the BBC and the press. While emotive, this is what many people directly affected by Brexit feel is happening.For example, on the matter of Germans buying our fish without a trade agreement the tarf will be  per cent on our fish exports to the EU. The Germans will no longer buy our fish.We can all read about other examples of the harm being done in the press every day. The cost of implementing a no deal exit will be borne by all of us, through further austerity , increased taxes , increased national debt or a combination of all three. To my mind, such measures will indeed cause serious economic and social harm.While Brendan O#Hara received a minority of the votes in Argyll, the present government was elected  by less than  per cent of the  electorate.David Inglis, Ardrishaig.Sir,During this, National Air Ambulance Week , may I draw readers# attention to the amazing work of the country#s only charity-funded air ambulance service # Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance .Since  this le-saving service has been flying help and hope to communities all across Scotland in response to serious illness and injury.From our base at Perth Airport, we have responded to more than , time-critical emergencies and impacted on the lives of thousands # and the need goes on.The recently-established Scottish Trauma Network has seen four key major trauma centres created at hospitals in Glasgow, Edinburgh, Aberdeen and Dundee. The aim is to transfer all serious patients to one of these centres following pre-hospital emergency care within  minutes.The value of a helicopter air ambulance is therefore obvious.Working alongside the Scottish Ambulance Service#s air fleet, SCAA relies entirely on public donations to keep this vital resource flying.Please consider supporting SCAA in it#s le-saving work during a week when the country focuses on the crucial work of air ambulances everywhere.For further information please visit www.scaa.org.ukDavid Craig, chief executive, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulance , Perth AirportSir,I get a magazine called #Clean Slate#.In it this month is an article where a -year-old girl, Greta Thunberg, along with  other youth activists, have issued this invitation to adults around the world: #Starting on Friday September  we are going to kick-start a week of climate action, with a world-wide strike for the climate. We are asking adults to step up alongside us and make this a turning point in our history.#Greta Thunberg was welcomed by the Speaker of the House of Commons, the leader of the Labour Party and the Secretary of State for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. She also spoke at the elite gathering of business leaders in Davos and at the UN.In March , school strikes took place in more than , cities around the world. Again in May, in more than  countries, millions of pupils took to the streets to remind the world that the earth faces a climate emergency.The strike starting on September  coincides with the UN Climate Action Summit in New York. Millions of people in more than  countries will walk out of their work, homes and colleges and spend a day demanding action on the climate emergency.I hear that many in Lochgilphead High School are planning to do the same # well done!Let us join them on Friday September  between am and pm to help build a future fit for all living beings.Mary Stirling, Ardrishaig

title: proposed tarbert pylons a plea from history
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsFor more than , years Tarbert has played an important part in Scottish history.The oldest financial records known to exist in Scotland record the work, started in  and carried out by Robert the Bruce, in rebuilding an earlier castle at Tarbert. Two men were paid to accompany Patrick the Fool on his journey from England to provide entertainment for the King and his guests while residing at Tarbert.Also recorded is a figure for #making a suit for the King at Tarbert#.  Bruce visited Tarbert on many occasions. His final visit was in the year of his death.Tarbert is believed to have been one of the earliest Royal Burghs in Argyll. An early reference as such was made in . It is also said to have had one of the earliest paved streets in Scotland.King James IV also had a close connection with Tarbert. The addition of the #keep# to the castle, part of which still stands today, was constructed at his direction. Whilst this work was underway, James summoned parliament to meet him here to discuss matters local to the area. This meeting took place on July  .Over the years, many travellers of note have passed this way and commented on Tarbert and its scenic surroundings.In  Thomas Pennant arrived by sea at East Loch Tarbert and described the scenery as #picturesque#.CGS Teighnmouthpassed through the Kyles of Bute in  and commented that #it offers no scenery worthy of notice#. He continued to note that #the romantic little harbour of East Loch Tarbert – with the overhanging keep of its ruined castle # form a scene singularly picturesque#. He became a frequent visitor to Tarbert.In  Lord Cockburndescribed the Kyles as #rugged and picturesque# but, arriving at his destination, exclaimed: #But Tarbert! East Tarbert! How is it that I had never even heard of that curious little bay. There it lay, calm and silvery, like a scene from a theatre. A striking and beautul spot.#In the modern era, many thousands of tourists visit Tarbert each year. Since the beginning of , more than , visitors have been recorded as accessing the Tarbert Castle site.Tarbert Harbour Authority manages one of the largest marinas in the Clyde area. Around  resident berth holders and more than , visiting leisure craft during the sailing season add considerably to the numbers who arrive at Tarbert and appreciate the attractive surroundings.The present plans for the power line, however, as exhibited by SSEN, will present a view on entering the harbour despoiled by a line of monster pylons.The current proposal suggests that four or five of the -foot pylons will dominate the western skyline. The visual impact of this scheme as presently proposed will have a negative effect on the experience of everyone who lives in, or visits, Tarbert.Tarbert was designated as a conservation area in the s. Argyll and Bute Council imposes restrictions on works likely to have a visual impact on its appearance.But the council has apparently raised no objection to this visually damaging proposal. Similarly, Visit Scotland is reported as having raised no objection as well as closing all its tourist offices in Cowal, Mid Argyll and Kintyre in the past year.With the recent decline in the Loch Fyne fishing industry, Tarbert is increasingly dependent on tourism to provide employment.Other issues include the sterilisation of ground under the proposed line of overhead wiring. Opportunities to extend social housing will be restricted under the present plan.OFGEM administers a £ million fund set up to mitigate the impact of electricity infrastructure on national parks and #scenic areas#.Tarbert, along with its harbour and the isthmus linking it with West Loch Tarbert, without doubt, constitutes a #scenic area#.Reconsideration of this proposal is essential.

title: duo delights in ardrishaig
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowBy Eve MaxwellMid Argyll Arts Association launched its new season on Saturday September  at Ardrishaig Public Hall with a fantastic duo.Katherine Aitken – a graduate of both the Royal College of Music and the Royal Academy of Music, London # is a Scottish mezzo-soprano with a rich caramel chocolate quality to her voice. Her partner Rebecca Taylor read music as an organ scholar at Lincoln College, Oxford before attending the Royal Academy of Music where she was a Junior Fellow and completed the MA in Piano Accompaniment.The audience were introduced to the pair with an intense piece by Mozart about burning letters and it certainly woke us up. We moved onto Schubert’s #Du Bist Die Ruh# which was beautully controlled by both singer and pianist.This was contrasted with Shubert’s angsty #Gretchen am Spinnrade# and I commend Rebecca Taylor for playing the right hand part with ease. The journey then moved through Schumann and into Brahms where the audience murmured in agreement at the rollercoaster of emotions before us.As we reached Wolf the themes took a darker turn in a short but intense piece about crying tears of blood. Swtly moving onto Strauss and Mahler the audience were given songs of simple love, a sing off between a cuckoo and a nightingale and a man in great pain which reigned the audience in with a spiritual lull.The second half opened with a stunning rendition of Faure’s #Apres Un Reve#. Through Debussy’s impressionist piece, Rinaldo Hahn’s Operatic journey and into Du Parc comforting his love with a dream like harp created by the piano.The duo then gave us a contemporary piece by Joseph Horowitz which comprised of snippets from the monologues of Shakespeare’s Lady Macbeth and the music tracks her descent into madness. It was aAs a light and fun ending we were given #I can be a sexy lady#, a piece about poor mezzos and how they always play boys and not much  in operas. I highly recommend you Youtube it for a bit of light entertainment.The partnership between the two is one I have not seen all that often and you can tell that they really enjoy working together.
